author: Jacqueline Le
title: Young Sydney woman Tanami Nayler driver of car Nicholas Michael Davison ran red light before Melbourne fatal crash - Yahoo7
text:
Sydney woman 'tried to run for life' before she was hit and killed by stolen car Jacqueline Le - AAP Share Share Young Sydney woman Tanami Nayler driver of car Nicholas Michael Davison ran red light before Melbourne fatal crash - Yahoo7 Young Sydney woman Tanami Nayler had only been in Melbourne for a few hours to visit a friend when a speeding driver ran a red light in an stolen car and killed her. Close News break - February 22 UP NEXT VIDEO Hunt for Karen Ristevski's killer, Sydney house inferno, Egg the pug not poached, Medical marijuana to be legalised, and more... News break - February 22 The NSW woman died instantly when a car driven by New Zealander Nicholas Michael Davison struck her as she crossed the road on July 30 last year. Davison pleaded guilty in the Victorian County Court on Wednesday to five charges, including culpable driving causing death, reckless conduct endangering life, and failing to stop after a fatal accident. Tanami Nayler was visiting a friend in Melbourne when she was struck and killed by a stolen car. Picture: Facebook Tanami pictured with her parents Vivien and Don on her 21st birthday. Picture: Facebook The 23-year-old man also pleaded guilty to breaking into a car rental office and stealing the car he was driving. Ms Nayler, 24, was killed hours after she flew into Melbourne from Sydney to spend the weekend with a friend to celebrate a recent job promotion. Prosecutor Jeremy McWilliams said it was about 2.30am when Ms Nayler and her friend began their walk home and crossed the intersection at the corner of King St and Hawke St in the city centre. "She attempted to run to avoid the vehicle, but there was no time to avoid being struck," Mr McWilliams said. A friend said Ms Nayler was walking about one to three metres in front of him. Ms Nayler tried to run to avoid the car, the prosecution claimed. Picture: Facebook "I heard a car screeching and then she said 'oh my God'," he told police. "The car hit her and didn't slow down. I couldn't see where she went, she just wasn't there anymore." Davison was allegedly driving at more than 150km/h when he struck Ms Nayler. "The force of the impact carrying her body 84 metres, where she then struck a traffic control signal and a street sign... her body travelling a further 10 metres," the prosecutor claimed. Davison lost control of the car after the collision and hit a pole before he allegedly fled the scene. Tanami Nayler died at the scene. Pictures: 7 News "The accused immediately ran from the crashed vehicle, across the intersection and past Ms Nayler's body," Mr McWilliams claimed. Davison allegedly disposed of his clothes before he was arrested 45 minutes later. A blood sample was taken about 10 hours later and it's estimated his blood alcohol reading at the time of the crash was allegedly between 0.129 and 0.228. The plea hearing before Judge Christopher Ryan continues. Share Share Young Sydney woman Tanami Nayler driver of car Nicholas Michael Davison ran red light before Melbourne fatal crash - Yahoo7
